Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Arctic Oases - How does the delayed release of winter discharge from aufeis affect the ecosystem structure and function of rivers
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a preliminary study to assess the potential effects of aufeis on the structure and function of arctic river-floodplain ecosystems. Aufeis are massive accumulations of ice common to many arctic rivers, particularly in northeastern Siberia and the North Slope of Alaska. River aufeis form during freeze-up when thickening surface ice and permafrost restrict river discharge, causing water to overflow existing ice. Successive cycles of overflowing and freezing of water from upstream groundwater sources accumulate enormous quantities of ice, with late-winter aufeis on some rivers attaining thicknesses of 3 to 5 meters, covering up to 20 square kilometers in some Alaskan fields (even larger in Siberia), and storing as much as a third of the annual discharge of the river in the form of ice. In addition, aufeis maintain an unfrozen base throughout winter due to the release of latent heat as water is converted to ice, which warms the underlying sediments, and a thick insulating layer of ice above. Although aufeis have been studied by hydrologists and are known to be required for winter and spawning habitat for important local fish species, understanding of their ecology is poor. In recognition of this, these investigators will conduct a targeted assessment of the ecological importance of a single aufeis field on the Kuparuk River, Alaska as a first step toward developing a hypothesis-driven research program.

The investigators propose that aufeis be viewed as winter oases due to their wet bases that supply water and heat to otherwise frozen habitats. Aufeis also function as summer oases by providing a stable supply of water to riverbed and downstream habitats. This preliminary study will focus on assessing 1) river flow and nutrient chemistry above, within, and below the aufeis field, and 2) the potential for year-round, unfrozen habitat beneath the aufeis field. The investigators will collect water samples for nutrient analysis in transects extending 2.5 km upstream and downstream from the aufeis field. They will collect hourly data on river stage, temperature, and electrical conductivity along each transect. They will also install pairs of piezometers to depths of 1 meter and 2 meters to measure the vertical hydraulic gradient between the underlying aquifer and the surface channel, and dissolved oxygen, temperature, and electrical conductivity of hyporheic waters at these points. Measurements of vertical hydraulic gradient will determine whether river reaches are generally upwelling or downwelling. To estimate volume and the potential seasonal contributions of the aufeis to river discharge they will use precise digital elevation models created from low-altitude vertical photogrammetry. Year-round temperature and electrical conductivity records will provide data for simple end-member mixing analyses to determine the proportion of aufeis meltwater to the river during the thaw season. During freeze-up and into the winter, these records will provide estimates of potential downstream influences of the spring-water downstream of the aufeis if subsurface flow is maintained. In order to assess the vertical influence of aufeis, the investigators will instrument nine transects with digital temperature loggers. They anticipate that loggers directly under the aufeis will never record temperatures below freezing but that those outside the aufeis footprint will. The investigators also propose August and April ground-penetrating radar surveys to determine thaw depths. Finally, PVC wells penetrating about one meter below the surface will be used to sample small invertebrate animals living in river sediments and below aufeis. The project will support two masters-level graduate students and will involve two undergraduate field assistants in the summer fieldwork.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Spring-fed streams with year-round flow and relatively constant water temperatures of 3-7oC or more are widespread on the arctic North Slope of Alaska, where most headwater streams freeze completely during winter when air temperatures are often below -30oC.  The water discharged from these springs originates from aquifers flowing beneath the permafrost layer that are subject to geothermal warming. Although such “warm springs” contribute only ~1% to the headwater stream length on Alaska’s North Slope, they also provide 100% of flowing stream habitat during winter. An interesting partner habitat to these springs are massive ice features known as river aufeis. River aufeis form during winter when water flowing downstream from a spring’s source cools and eventually freezes. The combination of thickening surface ice and permafrost below constricts the stream channel, resulting in cycles of overflow and freezing that form aufeis. In Alaska, aufeis may reach thicknesses of 3 to 7 m and may cover areas up to 80 km2.

Aufeis are significant to the ecology of the Arctic. During summer, for example, they provide meltwater to downstream river reaches that would likely dry, thus facilitating migrations of fish along stream corridors. They also provide seasonal habitat for fishes and mammals and a form of disturbance that maintains characteristic plant communities. Notwithstanding such anecdotal observations, understanding of the ecology of aufeis as ecosystems is poor at best. To remedy this, we initiated a project that rigorously explored the ecology of a single aufeis. We were particularly interested in testing a prediction that during winter the insulting ice layer of an aufeis may result in extensive groundwater habitats that would otherwise be frozen, which would likely have significant consequences for understanding patterns of arctic biodiversity.

Our main goals were to assess: 1) the occurrence of year-round, unfrozen groundwater habitat beneath the Kuparuk River aufeis on the arctic North Slope of Alaska, and 2) the potential occurrence of a subsurface invertebrate community there. The size of this aufeis varies seasonally, being greatest during late winter when it may cover 8+ km2 and reach thicknesses up to ~7 m; it is readily visible via Google Earth (68.980084, -149.713316). To meet our first goal, which was to assess the occurrence of year-round, unfrozen groundwater habitat, we used a combination of ground-penetrating radar (GPR) and surface nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) to quantify conditions beneath the aufeis during maximum ice sheet development in April. During April 2017, an ice layer up to 6 m thick (i.e., the aufeis sheet) overlying 3 to 5 meters of frozen sediments was detected.  More importantly, a region of unfrozen sediments below the frozen surface layer was also detected. In some areas this feature formed a ~13-m thick layer of unfrozen, water-saturated sediments, indicating that an extensive volume of unfrozen groundwater habitat did indeed occur beneath much of the aufeis field. Further, discrete zones of groundwater upwelling indicated direct connection during winter between the aufeis surface and the underlying aquifer. These findings indicate that, even during winter, the Kuparuk River aufeis maintains a significant and dynamic subsurface volume of unfrozen, saturated sediments during winter. 

Our second goal was to search for a groundwater invertebrate community beneath the aufeis field.  To sample potential groundwater invertebrates, 50 3.5-cm diameter PVC wells were installed in ~40 ha grid within the aufeis field.  Sampling consisted of sieving a known volume of water from each of the wells. The results of this effort showed that the Kuparuk River aufeis ecosystem did indeed provide year-round subsurface habitat for a rich assemblage of freshwater invertebrates that is distinct from those occurring in surface habitats. This was the first demonstration of a groundwater invertebrate fauna in any region of continuous permafrost.  The number of specific types of invertebrates from wells (about 49 types) and surface habitats (about 43 types) were similar, which was surprising given the lower richness in subsurface habitats in large gravel-bed river systems elsewhere. This may be explained by greater variability of subsurface habitats that likely contributed to higher species turnover among habitat patches compared with surface sediments. One significant habitat characteristic that was shown to affect groundwater invertebrate diversity within the aufeis field was whether habitat patches contained upwelling or downwelling water, a factor that has also been shown to underlie spatial patterns of subsurface communities of temperate-zone gravel-bed rivers.

Past studies of aufeis have focused on their physical hydrology with little attention devoted to their ecosystem characteristics and roles. Our study, however, has definitively demonstrated the presence of a significant unfrozen, year-round groundwater habitat as much as 13 m thick beneath the Kuparuk River aufeis field. More significantly, the results of this explorative study provide the first report of a groundwater invertebrate community in a region of continuous permafrost and formally recognizes aufeis as significant freshwater ecosystems in the Arctic.
